entry.title: Responsible Vibe Coding Tutorial: Building a Meeting Room CAP App
entry.content:
üéØWhat is Vibe Coding?

Vibe coding means collaborating with AI assistants to build apps step by step, entirely through natural language prompts. Instead of writing everything yourself, you ‚Äúvibe‚Äù with AI to generate, refine, and optimize code.

This tutorial shows how to build a Meeting Room Booking app with CAP + AI Core, entirely through prompts ‚Äî from schema to service, business logic, AI integration, and a simple UI.

 

Quick prerequisites

  • VS Code + Cline extension (or your Claude integration)
  • Node.js (v18+) and @SAP/cds-dk (CAP CLI)
  • SAP BTP account with AI Core (for production); we include a dev fallback.
  • Git repo and .clinerules set up (recommended)

Step 0 ‚Äî Plan first (Cline Plan mode)

Always start with a short Plan prompt to the AI (Cline Plan mode). Example plan template:

Plan:

- Goal: Add a MeetingRoom CAP service with Book/Cancel/Search and a recommendRoom AI action.

- Acceptance criteria: CDS created + seed data; BookService exposing actions; recommendRoom returns top-3 rooms with reasons; endpoints testable via curl.

- Assumptions: No auth (dev), timezone = UTC, single-tenant.

- Edge cases: overlapping bookings, zero-capacity rooms, invalid room IDs.

- Tests: curl examples for create/search/recommend and a UI smoke test.

Part 1: Setting Up the Environment

üé§The Prompt:

Set up a new CAP project for a meeting room booking system.

üí°What Happened:
The AI guided installation, created a new CAP project, and initialized dependencies.

Generated Commands:

npm install -g @SAP/cds-dk

cds init meeting-vibe

cd meeting-vibe

npm install

Key Learning: Always start with a clean project skeleton before vibing features.

Part 2: Creating the Data Model

üé§The Prompt:

Create a data model with Rooms and Bookings. Rooms have capacity, location, amenities, and availability. Bookings track user, room, start/end times, and status. Include seed data.

üí°What Happened:
The AI generated the core CDS schema and sample CSV seed files.

üìÇGenerated Schema:

namespace vibe.meetings;

 

entity Rooms : cuid, managed {

  name      : String(111) not null;

  location  : String(111);

  capacity  : Integer;

  amenities : String;

  available : Boolean default true;

}

 

entity Bookings : cuid, managed {

  room    : Association to Rooms;

  userId  : String(36);

  start   : Timestamp;

  end     : Timestamp;

  purpose : String(255);

  status  : String(20) default 'CONFIRMED';

}

Key Learning: A single domain-level prompt is enough to generate a correct schema with relationships.

Part 3: Adding the Service Layer

üé§The Prompt:

Expose the Rooms and Bookings as a BookingService with actions: bookRoom, cancelBooking, searchAvailableRooms, and recommendRoom.

üí°What Happened:
The AI produced a full CDS service definition.

üìÇGenerated Service Definition:

service BookingService {

  entity Rooms as projection on vibe.meetings.Rooms;

  entity Bookings as projection on vibe.meetings.Bookings;

 

  action bookRoom(roomId: UUID, userId: String, start: Timestamp, end: Timestamp, purpose: String) returns Bookings;

  action cancelBooking(bookingId: UUID) returns String;

  function searchAvailableRooms(start: Timestamp, end: Timestamp, minCapacity: Integer) returns array of Rooms;

  action recommendRoom(start: Timestamp, end: Timestamp, attendees: Integer, prefs: String) returns array of {

    roomId: UUID;

    score: Decimal(5,2);

    reason: String;

  };

}

Key Learning: The AI can infer the exact CRUD operations and business functions you need if you describe them clearly.

Part 4: Business Logic Implementation

üé§The Prompt:

Implement handlers for bookRoom, cancelBooking, and searchAvailableRooms in JavaScript with validation and error handling.

üí°What Happened:
The AI generated a srv/book-service.js with full logic for booking, cancelling, and searching.

üìÇExample Implementation:

this.on('bookRoom', async (req) => {

  const { roomId, userId, start, end, purpose } = req.data;

  if (new Date(start) >= new Date(end)) req.error(400, 'Invalid time range');

  const overlap = await SELECT.one.from(Bookings).where`room=${roomId} AND start < ${end} AND end > ${start}`;

  if (overlap) req.error(409, 'Room already booked');

  const booking = await INSERT.into(Bookings).entries({ room_ID: roomId, userId, start, end, purpose });

  return booking;

});

Key Learning: When you ask for validation + error handling, the AI adds production-quality safeguards.

Part 5: AI-Powered Recommendations

üé§The Prompt:

Add AI integration with SAP AI Core to suggest the best rooms. Include a fallback heuristic when AI Core is not configured.

üí°What Happened:
The AI created srv/ai-recommender.js, with both AI Core and fallback logic.

üìÇExample Snippet:

async recommendRooms({ start, end, attendees, prefs, rooms }) {

  if (!this.config.clientId) {

    return rooms.map(r => ({

      roomId: r.ID,

      score: r.capacity >= attendees ? 80 : 50,

      reason: `Capacity ${r.capacity} vs ${attendees}`

    })).slice(0,3);

  }

  // AI Core integration here...

}

Key Learning: Always request a fallback path ‚Äî AI assistants can build graceful degradation into your app.

Part 6: Building a Simple UI

üé§The Prompt:

Create a simple SAP UI5 page with fields for start/end time, attendees, preferences, and a button to call recommendRoom. Show results in a table.

üí°What Happened:
The AI created view/Main.view.xml with a table bound to the recommendation endpoint.

üìÇExample View Snippet:

<VBox>

  <DateTimePicker id="start"/>

  <DateTimePicker id="end"/>

  <Input id="attendees" placeholder="Attendees"/>

  <Input id="prefs" placeholder="Preferences"/>

  <Button text="Recommend" press=".onRecommend"/>

  <Table id="tblRooms">...</Table>

</VBox>

Key Learning: Even complex UI scaffolding can be generated quickly when you specify layout + bindings.

Part 7: Documentation & Testing

üé§The Prompt:

Create a TESTING_GUIDE.md with curl commands to test all service actions.

üí°What Happened:
The AI wrote a full Markdown testing guide with:

  • curl for bookRoom, cancelBooking, searchAvailableRooms, recommendRoom
  • expected responses
  • error case examples

Key Learning: Ask for docs and tests explicitly ‚Äî they are as important as code.

üéØBest Practices for Responsible Vibe Coding

  • Engineer > AI: Review, understand, and own every line.
  • Test Before You Trust: Validate edge cases with curl or UI.
  • Plan First: Use Cline Plan mode before big prompts.
  • Fallbacks Matter: Always ask AI to build dev-safe fallbacks.
  • Docs Are Not Optional: Generate and maintain documentation with prompts.

üèóÔ∏è What We Built Together

Through prompts alone, we created:

  • üìäData Layer: Rooms & Bookings entities with seed data
  • üîßBusiness Logic: Booking, cancellation, search with validations
  • ü§ñAI Integration: Room recommendations with AI Core + fallback
  • üé®UI: Simple SAP UI5 page for booking and recommendations
  • üìöDocs: A testing guide for backend and UI

üéâCongratulations!

You‚Äôve just built a Meeting Room Booking CAP app by vibing with AI ‚Äî responsibly. The secret: always combine AI‚Äôs speed with your engineering judgment.

üìñLearn More

  • SAP CAP Documentation
  • SAP AI Core Documentation
  • Cline Extension

entry.title: New Developer- and SAP-Technology Forums/Groups
entry.content:
Dear "Application Development and Automation" group members/subscribers, 

In case you haven't seen the general announcement post that went out earlier this week, this blog post is to inform you that we launched a pilot of new developer- and SAP-technology related forums/groups this week.

For you, this means that while the pilot runs, the "Application Development and Automation" group is set to read-only.
We would like to encourage you to go to our new developer forums/groups, if you would like to ask or answer questions, or publish blog posts, on development/technology-related topics. 

There are a number of different reasons why we would like to test these new forums/groups: 

  1. Since our platform migration last year, we have received feedback that you didn't know where to go to find topics like ABAP, Integration or UI5. With these new developer forums/groups, we hope we have made it easier for you to find the technology topics you are most interested in.

  2. We noticed that the discussion board in this group was used to ask development related-questions. Generally, everyone has been very helpful answering questions asked here. However, our interest groups are for having conversations with, and connecting to, like-minded people around shared interests. This is why these groups have discussion boards (= for conversations) and blog posts, instead of Q&As/forums. Therefore, when someone asks a question in the "Application Development and Automation" discussion board, it is not possible for the author to accept the right answer as a solution. This again means, that if someone with the same problem comes to the community to get help later on, they will not be able to see what the solution to the problem was.
    Which brings us to no. 3 below:

  3. Because answers to questions in discussion (conversation) boards won't have accepted solutions, we are also not able to give credit to, or celebrate, the members who took the time to help answer questions.

  4. With the new developer forums, authors can accept any answer as a correct solution, which means we will be able to bring back our topic expert leaderboards, and give proper credit to our members who answer questions.

  5. A new denser forum feed, with no preview of content, making it easier to scroll down the feed to look for the questions you can help answer: 


  6. New filter for "Questions with no answers". 
    This long-requested filter has now been added to all new Developers forums, so that you can find all questions with. no answers on a specific topic with one click: 
  7. We can now highlight important product announcements, or other valuable content, you shouldn't miss, around your favourite development topics by using the "Featured Topics" section for the individual topics.

  8. Better subscription management.
    You will now be able to subscribe to either all developer/SAP-technology related content, or drill down to and only subscribe to the specific parts that interest you the most:
    1. Developers https://community.sap.com/t5/developers/ct-p/developers - here you can subscribe to the whole category, this subscription sends you notifications on the platform and email notifications according to your account settings. 
    2. The individual groups, with both the Forums and Blog posts - here taking ABAP Cloud as an example: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud/gh-p/abap-cloud - here you have the same subscribe option as above. If you subscribe to content here, it will send you notifications on the platform and email notifications according to your account settings. 
    3. The individual group boards, ABAP Cloud Forum: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud-forum/bd-p/abap-cloudforum-board - here you have both the option to Subscribe and Subscribe to RSS Feed. The Subscribe option is the same as the two options above, and the RSS Feed is the one you are looking for. 
      You will find the same options for the blog posts boards as well: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud-blog-posts/bg-p/abap-cloudblog-board


If you missed the main announcement post, you can find more information in this What's New blog post. 

We hope you hop over to the new Developer groups to try them out üôÇ 
If you have any feedback to us on the forums, you can provide it in the comments section on the What's New post linked above.

entry.title: New in SAP Profile: Your Recent Activity Feed
entry.content:
We‚Äôre excited to announce a new feature in the SAP Profile: the Recent Activity feed.

From now on, whenever you publish a blog post, answer a question, or engage in other activities in SAP Community, your contributions will automatically appear in a dedicated feed on your personal SAP Profile page.

In the screenshot below, the areas marked in red and green highlight the new features (the color boxes are only for illustration and not part of the actual design):

  • Red box: the new Recent Activity feed. It supports infinite scrolling, allowing you to explore your past activities without any limit.

  • Green box: the new Reputation section, which we will continue to enhance by adding data from additional SAP touchpoints over time.

The section highlighted in the green box also shows the newly introduced Reputation section. We will continue to expand this section and add data from other SAP touchpoints. 

Why this matters

Your SAP Profile is the central place where others can learn more about you, your expertise, and your community presence. With the new activity feed:

  • Your contributions shine ‚Äì Every blog post, answer, or update you share becomes more visible.

  • Your expertise is easier to discover ‚Äì Visitors to your profile can now quickly see your most recent activities.

  • Your profile feels more complete ‚Äì It‚Äôs not just a static page anymore, but a living reflection of your engagement.

How it works

The feed updates in near real-time, powered by a new event-based architecture that our team built not only for this feature, but also as a foundation for future scenarios. Event-based systems are a powerful architectural pattern that allows us to deliver updates quickly and reliably ‚Äî and you‚Äôll see more benefits of this approach in upcoming enhancements.

To make the feed even more engaging, we‚Äôve included images alongside the activity updates. This makes the stream more visually appealing, more useful, and easier to understand at a glance. While adding images added some complexity, the result is well worth it for the user experience.

Go ahead and check your SAP Profile today ‚Äî your personal feed is already waiting for you!

entry.title: Can SAP‚Äôs Real-Time Analytics Redefine Decision-Making for the C-Suite?
entry.content:
The Changing Role of Leaders

Today‚Äôs CEOs and CTOs face more data than ever before. Numbers flow in from finance, supply chain, and customers. The challenge is not access. The challenge is speed. Leaders cannot wait days for reports. They need answers now.

Why Real-Time Matters

Traditional reporting works on past data. By the time insights reach the boardroom, the market may have moved. Real-time analytics flips this model. It brings live data from operations straight to decision-makers. A CEO can see global sales by region as they happen. A CTO can monitor system health before an outage hits.

How SAP Enables This

  • SAP HANA: stores and processes data in-memory for instant results.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): gives live dashboards and predictive models.
  • Embedded Analytics: in S/4HANA allows leaders to view insights while working inside core processes.

These tools cut delays and remove the guesswork.

Practical Example

Imagine a manufacturer facing a sudden raw material shortage. Without real-time analytics, the CEO learns of it after a weekly report. With SAP, alerts appear the moment supply drops. Leaders can adjust sourcing, update prices, and inform partners‚Äîall within hours, not days.

Best Practices for the C-Suite

  • Ask sharper questions: Real-time data works best when leaders know what to track.
  • Balance speed with accuracy: Not all data needs live updates. Focus on what drives action.
  • Build trust in data: If executives doubt the system, they will fall back on instinct.

Challenges to Watch

Real-time analytics is powerful, but not simple. Common issues include:

  • Integrating data from multiple systems.
  • Ensuring security and access control.
  • Training leaders to read dashboards, not just slides.

The Bigger Picture

Real-time analytics does not replace leadership. It sharpens it. CEOs still need vision. CTOs still need strategy. SAP‚Äôs role is to provide clear, trusted signals so leaders can act without delay.

Engage Further

The question for the C-suite is simple: Are you ready to let real-time data guide your next move? If you want to explore practical steps, connect with experts, or join discussions in the SAP Community.

entry.title: Want to Earn More Badges? Let‚Äôs Discuss!
entry.content:
Healthy discourse is a critical component for any community, and our latest badge progression set is designed specifically for members who kick these conversations off by starting discussions. 

As with the other progression badges that we introduced recently, this set will contain five badges that will be awarded retroactively ‚Äì meaning, if you‚Äôve already initiated discussions in the community, you may get one or more badges tomorrow (Thursday, October 9). You‚Äôll earn the first badge for the first discussion you started, the second for starting three discussions, the third for starting ten, and the fourth for starting twenty. If you‚Äôve been especially chatty, you may even get the fifth badge ‚Äì awarded for starting fifty discussions! 

If you‚Äôre unfamiliar with discussions in SAP Community, you‚Äôll find several lively ones within our various groups. We have groups for locations around the world, fun activities (such as Devtoberfest), common interests (including the community‚Äôs very own Welcome Corner), and more. 

Unlike the Q&A boards (where members seek solutions to their problems), discussions generally focus on an open topic and allow other members to share their thoughts and opinions. There‚Äôs no right answer ‚Äì just an invitation to participate in a friendly chat. 

If you‚Äôd like to start a discussion, first find a group that interests you. Click the big blue button near the top of the group‚Äôs page to join. You can‚Äôt miss it. (Note that some private groups may require that their owners approve your request to join, but you can join any public group right away with the click of the button.) 

If you try to start a discussion before joining a group, the option will be grayed out. 

 

Joining the group opens the option to start a discussion.  

 

While we understand that our badge enthusiasts may be eager to complete this new set quickly, please make sure that you only start discussions that are relevant to the corresponding group(s) in which you want to post ‚Äì and that the discussions are meant to encourage group members to participate in the conversation. Starting an off-topic discussion may earn you a badge, but it won‚Äôt generate any interest. A group owner or curator may even opt to remove the discussion if it doesn‚Äôt fit the group‚Äôs purpose. Best to spend some time in a group to get to know it and its members before starting a discussion there. 

Once you‚Äôre comfortable with a group (and feel confident you can strike up appealing discussions in it), take advantage of the opportunity to earn badges from the new set. Or if you‚Äôre already active in groups (with several discussions to your credit), you may earn one or more badges when we introduce the new set tomorrow. 

Want to know how many badges from this set you‚Äôre entitled to? Here‚Äôs what you need to do.  

Log in to SAP Community, then select ‚ÄúMy content.‚Äù 

 

Scroll down to the ‚ÄúPrivate Stats‚Äù section of your content page and look for the ‚ÄúDiscussions Started‚Äù entry. That number will help you determine how many badges coming your way tomorrow. For example, for the member below, he can expect badges for starting one, three, and ten discussions ‚Äì as his fourteen discussions are more than enough to earn him the first three badges in the set. He‚Äôll need to be a little more active in group discussions to earn the last two (for twenty and fifty discussions, respectively). Still, he‚Äôs well on his way to completing the set! 

We‚Äôll need a few hours to assign the badges tomorrow, and we‚Äôll award them one at a time from the lowest to highest. Our friend above can expect three notifications (one for each badge that he earned, beginning with the badge for starting his first discussion), and you can expect one or more yourself if you‚Äôve been actively starting discussions in the community. (If your badges haven‚Äôt shown up by Friday the 10th, make sure to log out and in again.) 

Don‚Äôt forget: These badges are meant to thank the members who take the time to make positive contributions to SAP Community. Answer a question, write a blog post that educates other members, leave a kudo on content that you enjoy, begin a friendly discussion. Each of those actions helps create a healthier, happier community ‚Äì and can earn you badges that show our appreciation.

entry.title: üü° Fun for Week 3: The Annual SAP Cryptic Crossword and Other Puzzles üß©üìù
entry.content:
As we do each Devtoberfest, we have published an all-new and improved SAP Cryptic Crossword. And ... we have 3 additional puzzles -- including new types of puzzles -- to challenge you even more.

TLDR: Here are the puzzles:

  • SAP Cryptic Crossword
  • SAP Cryptic Crossword Bonus
  • Scramble: Programming Languages
  • Scramble Event-Based Processes CodeJam

SAP Cryptic Crossword Puzzle

The centerpiece of the 2025 puzzles is again the SAP Cryptic Crossword. Just go to the crossword tutorial and you can complete it there: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-sap-crossword.html

The tutorial has some guidance on how to solve cryptic crosswords, but feel free to ask for help in this blog post.

üëâTIP: Best to print out the grid and clues, solve it, and then enter the answers in the tutorial.

There is also a bonus puzzle where you have to take some of the letters in the completed puzzle and derive the name of 2 of our esteemed Developer Advocates: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-sap-crossword-bonus.html

How an ex-CEO of SAP saved the day

I'm going to tell a story about embracing failure, laughing at yourself, and learning from your mistakes. But ...

üö®üö®üö®SPOILER ALERT - I will spoil one of the answers of the SAP Cryptic Crossword, so skip this section if you don't want to have that clue spoiled.

When I first started creating the puzzle, I had this area of the puzzle that needed a clue/answer:

Since the puzzle focused on developers, and I was quite familiar with SAP Build Apps functions, I thought of the function CIEL(), which rounds a number to the next integer. Perfect! I even had a really good clue.

Command to round up horrific lice

 Well, I gave the puzzle to @qmacro to test. And besides being able to complete it in what seemed like 5 minutes, he found an embarrassing error -- I HAD MISSPELLED THE NAME OF THE FUNCTION!! The function was CEIL() not CIEL()!

I literally cursed out loud when I saw the mistake üò†.

Well, it was quite difficult to somehow make the function's real name fit and to move the puzzle around. So I searched for another answer that would fit. And the first thing I thought of was BILL, as in the name of our former CEO (also a word contained in some of our business processes). Bill McDermott was the longest-serving CEO during my tenure at SAP.

And that's how Bill McDermott saved my puzzle.

Scramble Puzzles

I am a big reader of Games magazine, since high school. And one of the simpler but fun puzzles is one where you have to find 10 words by taking each one's clue, removing one letter and then rearranging the remaining letters to form a new word. And then you have to figure out the common denominator of all those words.

Here's one from a recent issue. Try it.

So I decided to create my own for Devtoberfest, one related to programming languages and one related to the Event-Based Processes CodeJam that I do with my good colleague @ajmaradiaga.

  • Scramble, Programming Languages: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-fun-scramble-languages.html
  • Scramble, Event-Based Processes CodeJam: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-fun-scramble-codejam.html

Admission: Not that difficult to make 

It is pretty easy to create these puzzles. You take an online Scrabble word finder app -- I use this one, https://scrabblewordfinder.org/. 

Let's say you are doing a puzzle on fruit, and you start with a possible answer like apple. You search for any word with those letters plus any other letter by adding a question mark.

Then you look for a word that looks the least like apple. Here, I would say upleap. And that's all you have to do.

entry.title: Protecting the integrity of the community content
entry.content:
Generative AI tools can be powerful aids when used thoughtfully, offering speed and inspiration, but they can also produce misleading or inaccurate results if applied without real expertise. Their value comes from being trained on years of human-created knowledge, yet that is also why our community must be careful in how they are applied.

Workflows are shifting as users adopt more efficient ways to get the information needed to complete their tasks.
But one thing remains constant: people come to our community because they trust the answers, posts, and discussions written by fellow members. To preserve that trust and ensure our content remains reliable, we need clear, shared guidelines on the responsible use of generative AI within our community. 

The slippery slope

At first glance, protecting content integrity by banning all GenAI-assisted content generation may seem a simple choice. But that would ignore the fact that GenAI can be a powerful aid in creating content (it even played a role in drafting this). The trick is developing guidelines that lets users take advantage of these tools to enhance their productivity. Consider this scenario:

About 75% of traffic in our community happens in the Q&A/Forums section, where people come looking for solutions to specific problems. The traditional workflow has looked something like this:

  • You run into a problem and start with a Google search.
  • From the results, you open a handful of promising pages, read through them, and piece together enough information to solve your issue or at least get enough of a hint.
  • If that doesn‚Äôt work, you post a question. If your post doesn‚Äôt include enough detail, there‚Äôs a back-and-forth in the comments until someone can provide a solid answer. That process may take time.

With generative AI, the workflow shifts:

  • You may still search as before.
  • More often, you open your preferred generative AI tool, start with a quick prompt, invest more time in writing a prompt if needed, and engage in a rapid back-and-forth until you get a usable answer or enough direction to move forward. In practice, the tool is drawing on nearly all available content at once.
  • If you still don‚Äôt get what you need, only then might you open a new question or discussion thread.

With this as a standard workflow now and access to many geneartive AI tools, it is tempting to take any unanswered question, paste it into a GenAI tool, copy the response and paste in the answer. The danger here is if the person posting the answer doesn‚Äôt actually know if it is correct or not.
This creates two problems if the answer is wrong:

  1. the original poster will believe it to be correct, try it, wasting their time and diminishing the perceived value of the community.
  2. if incorrect data remains in the community, it will be scraped by the generative AI models, used in their training or RAG systems, decreasing the quality of answers (until it is removed).

This community exists to share knowledge and experience between real people. AI tools cannot ensure accuracy, provide verifiable sources, or account for the nuances of real-world problem solving. Allowing AI-authored posts without the author verifying the content risks:

  • Spreading incorrect or misleading information.
  • Eroding the trust between members.
  • Diminishing the long-term value of our content.

Acceptable use of generative AI tools

You may use GenAI tools to help you plan, structure, or clarify your writing, as long as the final result reflects your own thoughts and tone.

Examples include:

  • Outlining your post or drafting a structure to build upon
  • Checking spelling, translation, or accessibility
  • Getting suggestions for phrasing, while keeping your own wording and perspective

If a generative AI tool meaningfully shaped your post (anything beyond the examples above like rewriting full paragraphs or producing a significant amount of the text), please disclose it by adding the predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label, or include a short note such as ‚ÄúThis post was assisted by GenAI.‚Äù For content where it's not possible to add a user tag, e.g., answers to questions and comments, you must include this statement: "This post was assisted by GenAI."

Doing so will provide the transparency needed to maintain credibility in the community.

A predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label can now be found throughout the community: 


Unacceptable use of generative AI tools

Posts that are primarily generated, rewritten, or reworded by AI are not allowed.

Examples include:

  • Submitting AI-generated answers to questions or forum threads
  • Submitting AI-generated articles or comments to content as your own
  • Using AI to ‚Äúpolish‚Äù a post so heavily that it loses your natural voice
  • Copying or pasting AI text directly from a prompt
  • Publishing content with little or no personal input or factual verification

Moderators may remove posts that read as machine-written or lack personal insight, regardless of the author‚Äôs stated intent.

A TLDR summary (intentionally at the end) or guiding principle is:

Anything you post in the community should represent your thinking, experience, and knowledge.
AI may assist you in the creation, but it cannot substitute for your voice. 
To keep your trust and add continual value to our members we must remain a community of people, for people, in our shared world of technology. 

The complete generative AI guidelines for the SAP Community can be found in our Welcome Corner group.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: From Stress to Strength - Running as My Lifelong Hobby
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I want to continue this blog series about SAP Community Hobbies.

It's amazing how you can meet people and discover new things in the community just through chatting and blogging with other members.

I want to say thank you to @act45 . I also remember him perfectly. In a world of work and technology, his presentation at the SAP Inside Track Copenhagen about mindfulness opened the doors to my mind to something that‚Äôs not just about hard work and software but also introspection and positive energy, which not many people share in their lives.

Another community member shifted her focus to something more important than just work, @sveabecker , and I would love for her to share her new path and dedication.

How I Started Running

As for me, I started running when I was young, in college. And why? Because of the stress from exams. Like Achim, I found a way to get rid of all my bad thoughts.

My first running shoes

 

I wasn‚Äôt working at the time, and I needed something inexpensive that I could do before a big exam.
Running was perfect.
Nothing competitive, just long-distance running. When I started, I didn‚Äôt even measure the distance. I used a stopwatch, and I‚Äôd stop after 20 or 30 minutes to go back home. Each time, I tried to go further than before.

What Running Means to Me Today

Years later, running has become more than just a way to handle stress. it‚Äôs part of my lifestyle.
When I travel for work or conferences, I always pack two pairs of shoes: one for work, and one for running. üòÅ
Exploring a new city through running gives me a completely different perspective compared to seeing it by car or train.

A fun race in NYC (Central Park) with my wife

 

 

And where I meet new friends, I joined running clubs in my new city in the U.S. They help me not only improve my pace but also meet new people. Running is no longer just a solitary activity for me; it‚Äôs about community and friendship, too.
I cannot wait to see my friends on Saturday to run together! 

Challenges and Lessons Learned (my angel wife)

Like many runners, I‚Äôve had my share of injuries. I struggled with knee pain, and it almost made me quit. Thanks to my wife, who encouraged me to see a physiotherapist, I learned the most important lesson: rest is as important as training.

Me running with my team

 

This applies not only to running but also to life and work. You can‚Äôt push endlessly without breaks. To achieve goals, balance and recovery are essential. Suggestion from my PT is also to do a lot of stretching that I include on a daily basis, and yoga has become a perfect sport to match. 

My Biggest Achievements

- My first half-marathon, at the time, it felt like a mountain, but today it reminds me how far I‚Äôve come.
- Running my own ‚Äúultra marathon‚Äù around the island of Manhattan, covering 57 km in one day. It wasn‚Äôt an official race, but it gave me immense joy and confidence.

Picture of my first solo marathon

 

 

Connecting Running with SAP Life

Running clears my mind after intense projects and helps me face the next challenge with more energy.

Just like in running, in SAP projects you need endurance, discipline, and trust that every small step will bring you closer to the finish line.

FUN FACT: In all the pictures you see with a cap. That is the SAP Community cap üòÑ I still running with it all the time üôÇ

Passing the Baton

I met @Sandra_Solis  at the last TechEd in the US. Sandra paints beautiful places she visits, and for me, running is also a way to travel and explore. While I run through streets and landscapes, Sandra captures them on canvas. Both of us, in our own way, transform experiences into something lasting.

If you want to connect on Strava and you are a runner, please feel free to add me here:
https://www.strava.com/athletes/26298351
And if you pass by NYC, don't hesitate to ask me to run üòÑ I will always accept.

 


Start with walking and then running: Have any of you recently run a race? And how do you train for running?

entry.title: Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)
entry.content:
Picture 1: Intelligent Enterprise Business Steering with SAP

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organization is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organizational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognizing these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organizational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organizations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support ‚Äì going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimize resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today‚Äôs business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  4. Is AI going to ‚Äúretire‚Äù a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today‚Äôs volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC 
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self ‚Äì service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

In our previous blog post, @BlazZabukovec highlighted how Planning & Analytics plays a vital role in SAP BDC by enhancing decision-making, boosting efficiency, and strengthening strategic alignment to drive organizational performance and business value.

So, what exactly makes up the SAP BDC ‚Äúmagic sauce‚Äù? Let‚Äôs dive in and unpack it. I will take you behind the scenes to explore the core Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC - powerful solutions that help businesses streamline planning, improve decision-making, and foster collaboration across departments. By diving into these capabilities, you will see how SAP BDC provides a trusted, unified platform that enables organizations to achieve more effective enterprise planning and analysis.

SAP BUSINESS DATA CLOUD ANATOMY

To start, we will explore the key features and innovations of SAP BDC to understand its core functionality and how it empowers effective enterprise planning and analysis. SAP BDC is a fully managed Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution provided by SAP. Customers simply subscribe to access and consume its powerful data services. Built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP BDC leverages foundational services that ensure scalability, security, and seamless integration across the enterprise ecosystem. At its core, SAP BDC harmonizes data from both SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer of trusted information. This unified data foundation enables organizations to perform planning, advanced analytics, fuel artificial intelligence, and derive actionable insights. By integrating structured and unstructured data across business processes, SAP BDC empowers companies to bridge transactional and analytical systems, driving intelligent, data-powered growth.

Picture 2: SAP Business Data Cloud Anatomy

SAP BDC builds on the strengths of existing SAP solutions, each contributing a vital layer to the overall architecture:

  • SAP Datasphere: Provides the data integration and modeling layer, ensuring consistent, trusted data across sources.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud: Delivers the planning, forecasting, simulation and analytics into a single solution.
  • SAP BW: ‚Äì When already in use, SAP BW can serve as a data source, enriching the overall data landscape with historical and structured information. You can materialize the BW data as custom data products in SAP BDC (BW Data Product Generator).

To complement these established tools, SAP BDC introduces new, powerful components and innovations designed to extend planning, analytical and data management capabilities:

  • SAP Databricks: Equips data scientists with advanced AI and machine learning development tools to unlock predictive and prescriptive insights.
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services: Provides centralized management of SAP and non-SAP data, ensuring governance, scalability, and efficient data lifecycle handling.
  • End-to-end data lifecycle managed by SAP: A key innovation of SAP BDC is that it automatically integrates and harmonizes data from all SAP LoB solutions, including S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, and Fieldglass. Data from these sources is replicated in real time, eliminating the need for customers to manually prepare and combine SAP data. With SAP managed Data Products in SAP BDC, you eliminate the heavy lifting of extraction, transformation, and pipeline maintenance. This allows organizations to focus on high-value projects, such as delivering Planning, Analytics, AI solutions, rather than time-consuming data preparation.
  • Unified Data Foundation: With SAP BDC, data from all SAP applications is unified under a single domain model. When multiple systems define the same entity - like a customer or product - SAP BDC brings them together under one harmonized definition. SAP BDC offers curated, reusable, and semantically rich data products- trusted assets delivered by SAP as the backbone of planning, advanced analytics and AI applications. Business users no longer need to worry about data origins; they work with consistent, trusted information. Plus, all valuable metadata from the source systems is preserved, ensuring no business context is lost during replication. Everything is grounded in trusted business context - so your AI isn‚Äôt guessing, it‚Äôs truly understanding.
  • Intelligent Applications: SAP BDC delivers ready-to-consume, fully managed by SAP Intelligent Applications that make planning and advanced analytics a business user task - not IT‚Äôs. Intelligent applications aren‚Äôt just static input forms or dashboards. They are dynamic, AI-powered systems of engagement that continuously learn from your business data, understand context, and act with precision. By bringing together curated data products, business semantics, and AI agents, these applications can reason, recommend, and even automate - whether you‚Äôre working in finance, supply chain, procurement, or HR. Planning and analytic workflows become proactive, decisions happen in real-time, and your business becomes more adaptive with every interaction. 

SAP BUSINESS DATA CLOUD ARCHITECTURE

Let‚Äôs take a closer look at the architecture of SAP BDC to understand how its core components work together to deliver value. As highlighted earlier, by unifying and managing data across the enterprise, SAP BDC establishes a trusted foundation that simplifies planning, strengthens analytics, and empowers smarter, faster decision-making. 

Picture 3: SAP Business Data Cloud Components

Here is a closer look at the core components and their roles:

  • Source Systems: The journey begins with source systems, which include both SAP (e.g., SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, SAP SuccessFactors) and non-SAP systems. SAP bundles business data from these systems into entities such as tables and views, combining them to represent specific business scenarios - like Sales, Spend, HR and Finance Performance, Margin Analysis, Substainable Business Performance, Working capital - before replicating them to SAP BDC.
  • Foundation Services: Once replicated, data is harmonized, transformed, and enriched in the Foundation Services, becoming reusable Data Products. Hosted on SAP HANA Cloud and Data Lake files, this layer fully manages integration, transformation, and cleansing, enabling seamless access for any planning and analytics use case.
  • SAP Datasphere: at the heart of SAP BDC, SAP Datasphere defines the data model for data products. It powers both pre-delivered Intelligent Applications and custom models, which can be extended with AI or machine learning. SAP Datasphere also manages analytical roles and data access, ensuring the right users see the right data. Mainly it serves as the foundational data layer for all planning and analytics use cases.
  • SAP Databricks: brings advanced analytics to SAP BDC through AI, machine learning, and pro-code engineering. Data products and planning models can be shared seamlessly (delta sharing protocol) between SAP BDC and SAP Databricks, enabling data scientists to enrich analytics and planning scenarios with sophisticated ML/AI logic. This empowers organizations to identify patterns, forecast outcomes, and automate decision-making. The insights generated in SAP Databricks can be integrated back into SAP Datasphere models, making analytics and planning applications even more powerful and actionable.The example below demonstrates how you can significantly enhance your BDC cashflow data product with advanced ML/AI logic to streamline cashflow forecast and provide deeper financial insights. Stay tuned for a dedicated post where we will explore these use cases in more detail.

Picture 4: Enrich BDC Data Products with ML/AI insights

  • SAP BW / SAP BW/4HANA: With its long history in SAP‚Äôs data and analytics ecosystem, SAP BW brings a wealth of legacy objects that remain valuable today. In SAP BDC, both SAP BW NetWeaver Cloud, private edition and SAP BW/4HANA Cloud, private edition can be integrated, allowing BW objects to be onboarded as fully usable data products (as highlighted in the SAP BDC Anatomy section). 
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): is an all-in-one enterprise planning solution that empowers businesses to analyze, plan, budget, forecast, and predict. With SAC, businesses can perform comprehensive planning, budgeting, and forecasting, make data-driven decisions with built-in business intelligence, gain trusted insights and automated forecasts powered by predictive analytics. It allows organizations to simulate multiple scenarios in a sandbox environment and facilitates cross-department collaboration through dynamic workflows. 
  • SAP BDC offers the SAP Seamless Planning approach, which tightly integrates SAP Analytics Cloud with SAP Datasphere. This allows SAC planning model data - including facts and master data - to be stored directly in SAP Datasphere. By blending live actuals and plan data through Datasphere‚Äôs capabilities, and referencing data in planning models without replication, organizations can significantly reduce their overall data footprint. This approach ensures real-time data availability while enabling advanced processing and extensibility scenarios through the combined power of SAP Datasphere and SAP Databricks. ( Seamless planning between SAP Analytics Cloud and ... - SAP Community )
  • Intelligent Applications: Intelligent Applications were described already at the SAP BDC Anatomy paragraph. Beyond custom planning input forms and visualizations, SAP BDC provides ready-to-consume SAP-managed Intelligent Applications via SAP Business Technology Platform. Actually they reduce time-to-value for data analysis and planning. For a comprehensive list of available SAP Intelligent Applications, please refer to the link. 
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit: is a key component in the SAP BDC landscape, providing users with easy access to pre-delivered Intelligent Applications and Data Products. Through the cockpit, users can quickly install applications, browse available data products, and share them with SAP Databricks to enhance analytics with AI and machine learning capabilities. This tight integration helps organizations build a trusted, advanced data foundation, powering smarter planning and analytics across the business.
  • SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM) is a powerful calculation engine built on SAP HANA that delivers real-time profitability and performance analysis. It enables users to create flexible models, process large volumes of data at high speed, and integrate seamlessly with both SAP and non-SAP systems. When deployed on SAP BDC, PaPM gains access to SAP BDC‚Äôs integrated ecosystem - including SAP Datasphere and SAC. Within the SAP BDC landscape, PaPM serves as an advanced calculation engine, empowering organizations to maximize performance and profitability through intelligent modeling and simulation. Combining PaPM and SAC allows users to run advanced profitability calculations and execute sophisticated data processing directly from the SAC interface. This integration enriches the planning process with enhanced computation capabilities and deeper insights.  PaPM also offers a range of prebuilt business scenarios - spanning both cross-industry and industry-specific use cases such as Profitability and Cost Management, Tax Modeling, and Transfer Pricing - to accelerate deployment and value realization.

SUMMARY

SAP BDC is a central hub for enterprise planning and analytics, providing a unified, fully managed platform that helps organizations turn data into actionable insights. Core components - SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, SAP Databricks, SAP BW and Intelligent Applications - enable businesses to streamline planning processes, perform sophisticated analyses, and make faster, more strategic decisions. By harmonizing data from SAP and non-SAP sources, SAP BDC creates a trusted foundation that supports advanced planning & analytics, AI, and intelligent applications. With SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM) in SAP BDC, organizations can run complex cost and profitability simulations, enhancing the accuracy and depth of planning. Collectively, these capabilities establish SAP BDC as a strategic asset for any organization aiming to optimize enterprise planning and drive measurable business value.

Do you want to embark on a journey? Please reach out to your SAP representative and register for your SAP BDC Discovery Workshop!

entry.title: Migrating SAP Profile and Microservices to SAP BTP Kyma
entry.content:
Over the past months, our SAP Community Portal team took on one of the most ambitious infrastructure projects in recent years: migrating the SAP Profile and the supporting microservices of the SAP Community Platform from SAP BTP Neo and SAP Converged Cloud (Kubernikus) to SAP BTP Kyma Runtime.

This was more than a technical migration: We wanted to strengthen our platform for the long term, simplify operations, and empower the team with modern cloud-native tools and practices.

Motivation

Over time, our platform had grown across multiple environments ‚Äî SAP BTP Neo and SAP Converged Cloud (Kubernikus) ‚Äî each with its own operational footprint and limitations. To continue evolving the SAP Community and SAP Profile, we needed a foundation that was both modern and sustainable.

Our goals were clear:

  • Increase development speed and efficiency through improved tooling, automation, and infrastructure

  • Reduce operational costs and complexity by adopting SaaS-managed databases and retiring legacy Neo Global Accounts

  • Address security and maintenance risks tied to the aging Kubernikus environment

Solution

To achieve this, we migrated a suite of critical services, including the Avatar Service, Subscription Service, Session Service, and Khoros Firehose Integration, to SAP BTP Kyma Runtime.
We also switched to SAP BTP PostgreSQL, introduced NATS for messaging, and integrated everything into Hyperspace build pipelines for streamlined CI/CD.

The transition required close collaboration between development, operations, and architecture teams. Careful planning, extensive testing, and phased rollouts helped ensure that users experienced no disruptions ‚Äî even as we moved the foundation of the platform beneath their feet.

SAP runs SAP

This migration is part of SAP‚Äôs broader transformation journey - applying our own cloud technologies internally and learning from the experience. By moving our services to SAP BTP Kyma, we‚Äôre contributing to SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúRun SAP on SAP‚Äù strategy and setting the stage for continued innovation in the years ahead.

To achieve this, we migrated a suite of critical services, including the Avatar Service, Subscription Service, Session Service, and Khoros Firehose Integration to SAP BTP Kyma Runtime. We also switched to BTP PostgreSQL, introduced NATS for messaging, and integrated everything into Hyperspace build pipelines for streamlined CI/CD.

Acknowledgments
Special thanks to @weckerle, @aliona_boltromeyuk, @hyerimm, @irene-glaz, @erikdietz284 as well as @MirkoFriedrich and @yaniv for leading this effort and to all consultants who contributed their expertise throughout the migration.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Pune 2025 ‚Äî A Celebration of Ideas, Energy, and Collaboration
entry.content:
Once again, the SAP community in Pune showed its strength, passion, and drive. On 11th October 2025, SAP Inside Track Pune returned for its second edition ‚Äî and it was nothing short of spectacular.

A Community Reunion

From the moment doors opened, the buzz in the air made it clear: this wasn‚Äôt just an event ‚Äî it was a community coming together. Over 200+ enthusiastic participants, 20+ speakers, and a dedicated team of volunteers gathered at SAP Labs India, ITPP, Pune to learn, share, and grow. The energy, camaraderie, and excitement were palpable.

ü§ù Voices That Inspire

We kicked off with an inspiring keynote by Saicharan Krishnamoorthy, tracing the journey of SAP Inside Track and spotlighting how far Pune has come on its SAP path. The stories shared, insights revealed, and vision laid out set a vibrant tone for the day.

The main stage was beautifully hosted by Punith Oswal (@Punith_Oswal), SAP Champion and member of the SIT core team. His energy and expertise set the perfect tone for the day‚Äôs sessions.

A Day of Deep Dive Learning

This year‚Äôs focus ‚Äî Business AI in SAP ‚Äî resonated through every session and conversation. From AI Strategy to Embedded AI, SAP BTP, modernization, and partner innovations, speakers took us on a rich journey of possibilities. Every talk, every case study, and every Q&A added layers of real-world relevance, innovation, and practical wisdom.

Sessions and Tracks

The event featured a variety of sessions divided across four different tracks, allowing attendees to dive deep into the topics that piqued their interest. Each session was packed with invaluable insights and the latest trends in the SAP ecosystem:

Gratitude to Our Pillars

Events like this don‚Äôt happen on their own. A heartfelt thank you to:

Our Esteemed Partners: Amazon Web Services, Rojo Integrations B.V , Mindset Consulting LLC,  Primus TechSystems, SAP Press - Your support and belief made this event a great success!

Our speakers, for generously sharing your stories, expertise, and bold ideas.

Our core team and volunteers, who poured time, energy, and love into every detail ‚Äî from logistics to hello smiles.

A huge shout-out to Saicharan Krishnamoorthy (@saicharank ) and Devprasad Kambli (@Devkambli) for leading the team from the front, your efforts went above and beyond to make sure everything came together flawlessly!

Unforgettable Moments and Key Takeaways

One of the standout aspects of SAP Inside Track Pune 2025 was witnessing the sheer enthusiasm and energy of Pune‚Äôs vibrant tech community. Professionals, learners, and SAP enthusiasts from across India came together to share knowledge, exchange ideas, and explore the latest innovations in the SAP ecosystem ‚Äî creating an atmosphere that was truly inspiring. The presence of participants who travelled from cities like Bangalore, Hyderabad, and Mumbai added incredible diversity and a sense of unity to the event.

Beyond the sessions and keynotes, the event was filled with opportunities to connect, collaborate, and build lasting relationships. Participants engaged with peers, SAP experts, and thought leaders ‚Äî sparking discussions that could lead to new collaborations, innovative solutions, and enhanced skills across SAP technologies and integration.

SIT Pune 2025 was more than just an event; it was a celebration of community, curiosity, and collaboration. Everyone ‚Äî from attendees to speakers, volunteers, and partners ‚Äî walked away with valuable insights and experiences, contributing to something truly special in Pune‚Äôs SAP ecosystem.

Looking Ahead

Reflecting on the success of SIT Pune 2025, the excitement for the future is palpable. Pune has firmly established itself on the SAP map, and this is just the beginning. The energy, passion, and ideas shared during this event have laid a strong foundation for even bigger opportunities, collaborations, and innovations in the years ahead.

Let‚Äôs keep the momentum going! If you couldn‚Äôt attend, make sure to follow our SAP Inside Track Pune pages on LinkedIn and join the SAP Pune Community group for updates, future events, and exclusive content.

The future of SAP in Pune is brighter than ever ‚Äî and we‚Äôre only getting started! 

A heartfelt thank you to everyone who made SIT Pune 2025 such a tremendous success. Here‚Äôs to many more milestones, learning, and moments of inspiration for the SAP community in Pune and beyond.

 

Until Next Time....

Cheers!

SAP Community Pune - Core Team

entry.title: SAP CodeJam HANA ML in Porto 2025-09 Recap
entry.content:
At the end of September, we held an SAP CodeJam event in Vila Nova de Gaia, Portugal. The event focused on exploring the foundations of AI applications with the SAP HANA Cloud: Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph Engine.

Thanks to the local host and organizers: @MatheusBrasil , @MRobalinho and the rest of the team...

...and participants!

It was great to have my teammate and fellow developer advocate @qmacro joining us... not only during the lunch break üêü

SAP CodeJam in Porto was the day before the very first SAP Inside Track there, so it was great to share a drink during a Stammtisch after the CodeJam...

 The following day, I had a chance to present the long story of LLM auto completion to AI agents‚Äîwe went in just three years! And invited everyone to join SAP TechEd to watch our Developer Keynote.

November is going to be an intensive month with SAP TechEd on Tour in Berlin, Sydney, and Bengaluru, followed by SAP CodeJams in Melbourne, Singapore, and the Middle East.

I always take the opportunity to experience at least a little bit of the city I am in, so you can see my photos: https://www.instagram.com/p/DPyfRcMDKko/?img_index=1

Would you like to host such an SAP CodeJam?

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: ABAP Innovations, Rules on GenAI for content creation and Devtoberfest recap!
entry.content:
In just the first two weeks of October, we‚Äôve already seen amazing blog posts from community members and SAP employees. Including step-by-step guides to make your ABAP journey smoother, new features in the Clean Core Cloudification Repository Viewer, SAP Joule for Developers hitting a new milestone and exciting new set of Badges!

Have you joined any Devtoberfest sessions yet? Participated in Fun Activities? Collected points along the way? We are also reminding you, that this free and online event is a must for the month!

Ans there‚Äôs plenty more initiatives and events happening across the SAP community all over the world. Let‚Äôs dive in and see what‚Äôs new!

Featured blog posts

New features on Clean Core Cloudification Repository Viewer  

Going through your SAP Clean Core journey? Then this overview about the new Clean Core Cloudification Repository Viewer (CRV), by SAP¬¥s Rudong_Liu, is a must read! With his hands-on experience supporting RISE with SAP Customers, he showed all the new features in this update version, that includes clearer interface with filters for product, release, state, and Clean Core levels. A highlight is the introduction of the ‚ÄúPartner Namespace‚Äù, which certified partners are now able to publish released APIs as well. Make sure to check the whole blog post, to have a look at the guide with images and explanations on how to navigate and improve the experience with CRV.

Read the blog post here

ABAP RAP ‚Äì How to Excel upload through custom action popup

Mass data changes that are uploaded via Excel, sometimes can be challenging because the execution often requires a custom action popup. Involving U15 extensions, third-party solutions or Object Page manipulations. But, on the latest blog post by the community member Ramjee Korada, he walks through the 10 steps on implementing the new ABAP/CAP annotations, that allows developers to prioritize implementing core business logic over developing reusable technical artifacts. This feature is currently functional on the BTP ABAP Environment.

Read the blog post here

News about SAP Joule for Developers and ABAP AI capabilities

Last week big news about accelerating ABAP innovation and transformation were released, and SAP¬¥s Sonja Lienard gave our members a full overview on the updates. Joule for Developers and ABAP AI capabilities are now available in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition 2025. Additionally, the new Custom Code Migration capabilities accelerate the transformation of classic ERP code to S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, including Documentation Chat (answers on SAP S/4HANA simplifications), ABAP Program Explain (purpose and logic of legacy code) and Explain for SAP S/4HANA Test Cockpit Issues (diagnosis and resolution using simplification items and cookbooks). Also, a big highlight is that SAP Joule for Developers will remain free of charge!

Read the blog post here

Pallets in SAP CPI Integration Flows

If you are trying to find a step-by-step on how to use Pallet in SAP CPI, the content produced by the community member Ankit Singh prepared, could be what you been looking for. Using the example of a toolbox, this feature allows to drag and drop frequently used patterns across different projects, making it more efficient so you don¬¥t have to rebuild every time. The key features are Process, Transformation, Mapping, Call, Routers, Persistence, Security, and Miscellaneous. Be sure to read the full description of each Pallet and make your own life easier when using the system!

Read the blog post here

Community News

New Progression Badges for Discussion!

Been an active member and speaking your mind also comes with rewards. Now our platform will give badges specifically for members who kick conversations off by starting discussions. The first badge for the first discussion you started, the second for starting three discussions, the third for starting ten, and the fourth for starting twenty. The biggest milestone is the fifith badge, awarded for starting fifty discussions! These five badges set will be awarded retroactively, which means that if you have already initiated discussions in the community, you will be notified. This is our way to recognize the members who take the time to bring positive contributions, educating other members, and connecting! Make sure to read here more details about it.

Preserving the integrity of the community content

We all know how Generative AI can accelerate learning, content creation, and sometimes be very useful. But our SAP Community team believes that it is only worth it when it is used thoughtfully. It is non-negotiable to us, the preservation of trust and accuracy. When someone copies and paste AI-generated answers without verification, the risk of spreading misinformation increases and we lose the essence behind the discussions on SAP Community.  It is highly recommended that if you need to use GenAI tools to draft, plan, and refine your content, the final text still reflects your personal expertise. Now ‚ÄúGenAI Assisted Content‚Äù label can be also found and added. SAP¬¥s Anne Petteroe explained all the details on her latest blog post here, and the examples of unacceptable usage. The complete generative AI guidelines for the SAP Community can be found in our Welcome Corner group. 

Have you shared about you on SAP Community Hobbies Series?

Last month, we shared the launch of the SAP Community Hobbies Series, which is a way of sharing the things you love to do and connecting with other members that maybe share the same interests. For this edition, we would like to shoutout our SAP Champion Sebastian Marchesini, that recently posted about his journey with running. This lifelong hobby, for Sebastian it became more than just a sport, but most importantly turned into an enjoyable moment, stress escapism and confidence booster for new challenges. Read here all about his lessons learned with running and join the series, because we would love to know more about what makes you happier!

Events

Devtoberfest 2-week Recap and Petoberfest!

Our SAP community has been showing up and bringing their best in the last two weeks of the Devtoberfest 2025, and first we would like to thank you for interacting and bringing such good energy to the sessions. Starting with ABAP and finishing with CAP, in case you missed or would like to give a second look on any speaker's presentations, here is the list for all last week agenda. Last but not least, the Fun Activities have been such a nice way to challenge everyone and earn points! And the biggest highlight goes for the Petoberfest, with the cutest images of our members' lovely pets (plus the AI generated dogs wearing SAP outfits!). You are definitely not going to regret taking a look at this adorable pictures here.  Let¬¥s not forget that for every activity is possible to earn points for the Grand Prize, the validation tutorials can be found in our Tutorial Navigator. 

Day in the life of a Developer at SAP TechEd

What an amazing way to kick off the SAP TechEd! And in case you are feeling that good anxiety for your days in Berlin, there are many ways to prepare yourself ahead. SAP¬¥s Richard Kuba shared his ‚ÄúDay in the life of a Developer‚Äù with his three days agenda including the sessions he is planning to attend. Richard also made sure to include his thoughts on why he thinks participating in SAP TechEd can be super valuable for real-world projects. We are sure that you will feel very inspired as well, so don‚Äôt miss it: SAP TechEd Berlin and Virtual happens from November 4 ‚Äì 6.  

SAP will co-host the next InnerSourceSummit!

The InnerSource Summit 2025 is happening on November 13, bringing nearly 24 hours of global content on hybrid format, from Yokohama, Berlin, and New York. Hosted by SAP, Mitsubishi Electric and IBM, this year‚Äôs summit marks the 10th anniversary of the InnerSource Commons Foundation. SAP¬¥s Guilherme Dellagustin, shared on his latest blog post on Berlin Location Group, more details about SAP participation on the event, the full agenda and how to register. If you are available, we encourage you to check it out and bring with you another SAP community member from your area to connect, learn and grow!
